analytic.title: Applied Mathematics and Computation

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Finite-time synchronization Memristor chaotic systems Memristor emulator circuit Image encryption

div.p: This paper investigates the finite-time synchronization of memristor chaotic systems (MCSs). First, an emulator circuit of memristor is designed to implement the MCSs. Then, based on the presented emulator circuit, the model of the MCSs is provided and its finitetime synchronization is successfully achieved under the proposed controller. Thereafter, the stability analysis of the closed-loop dynamics is derived and the effectiveness of the theoretical results is testified via numerical simulations. Finally, an image encryption algorithm is proposed based on MCSs. The statistical performance analysis reflects the effectiveness of the image encryption algorithm and shows its potential applications in secure communication.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: During the past decades, chaotic systems have attracted increasing attentions due to their potential applications in secure communication [1] . In chaotic systems, a minor change in initial states can generate a large error for the system response. Due to this characteristic, the academics kept believing that chaos is harmful until the concept of chaotic synchronization was first proposed in 1990 [2] . Thereafter, great effort s have been made to solve chaotic synchronization and chaos control problems. Besides, the results on synchronization of chaotic systems has been invoked in many practical applications, including image encryption, secure communication and information processing [3][4][5] . Therefore, many effective synchronization approaches have been proposed using different control methods, including adaptive control [6] , quantized control [7,8] , sampled-data control [9][10][11] , impulsive control [12,13] , state estimation control [14][15][16] , event-triggered control [17][18][19] .

It is worth pointing out that aforementioned investigations mainly focus on asymptotic synchronization of chaotic systems and the obtained convergence time is infinite, which becomes a bottleneck in practical applications. Therefore, finitetime synchronization is raised and extensively investigated [19][20][21][22][23][24][25] . In [20] , the finite-time synchronization of two complexvariable chaotic systems with unknown parameters was realized by using sliding mode control approach. In [21] , authors investigated the finite-time stabilization problem for a class of memristor-based networks. In [22] , the finite-time cluster synchronization of T-S fuzzy complex networks with discontinuous subsystems and random coupling delays was studied. In [23][24][25] , the finite-time synchronization of nonidentical, delayed and different dimensional chaotic systems was investigated.

The memristor chaotic systems (MCSs), as a new kind of chaotic systems, have been frequently referred to in recent years. Memristor is the abbreviation of memory resistance, well-known as being the fourth basic component in the circuit system predicted by Prof. Chua in 1971 [26] , and has been practically implemented by the HP Laboratory in 2008 [27] . The memristor's resistance changes with the current flowing through the circuit, and then is retained when the circuit is powered off. Memristor behaves a special nonlinear volt-ampere characteristic curve, which can improve the performance of chaotic systems. Thus, it has been widely adopted in chaotic systems, generating the MCSs [28][29][30][31][32] . In [33] , adaptive synchronization of memristor-based Chua's circuits was addressed by designing an adaptive controller. In [34] , fuzzy modeling and synchronization of different MCSs were proposed through the idea of fuzzy control. The energy consumption of memristor networks and optically coupled memristor Chua's circuits was investigated in [35,36] . Due to the pseudo-random property, unpredictability and initial sensitivity of MCSs, the informations, being required to be encrypted, can be hidden in chaotic signals, which are highly similar to noise. In [37] , the authors analyzed a MCS and proposed an image decryption algorithm for it. In [38] , an interesting encryption scheme for complex chaotic networks and its corresponding image statistical analysis were given. However due to high manufacturing costs and technical barriers, it is not realistic to use physical memristors directly in the circuits of MCSs. Hence, an emulator circuit being composed of many existing, commercially available circuit components should be designed to implement the memristor.

Motivated by the above discussions, this paper deals with the finite-time synchronization problem of MCSs and its corresponding applications in secure communication are implemented by a newly designed image encryption algorithm. The main contributions are three-fold. First, an emulator circuit, that behaves all the dynamic characteristics of memristor, is designed. Second, the criteria for finite-time synchronization of MCSs are derived. Compared to asymptotic synchronization of MCSs in [31][32][33][34] , finite-time synchronization possesses faster convergent speed and better disturbance rejection capability. Third, an image encryption algorithm is presented for applying the obtained results of finite-time synchronization to secure communication.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 , a circuit realization scheme of MCSs based on memristor's emulator circuit is proposed. In Section 3 , the mathematical model of MCSs is given and some lemmas are introduced. In Section 4 , a finite-time synchronization scheme for MCSs is designed. In Section 5 , the numerical simulations demonstrate the effectiveness and feasibility of this method. In Section 6 , an image encryption algorithm and its corresponding statistical analysis are presented. Finally, a conclusion is given in Section 7 .

div.head: Circuit realization of MCS
div.p: Memristor is considered as the missing fourth passive circuit element and can be divided into flux-controlled memristor and charge-controlled memristor. A number of mathematical models have been proposed for memristors and one of the most widely used models is the following cubic function model [39] . For the cubic function model, the memristor has a smooth cubic monotonous rise nonlinear characteristic curve expressed as q (ϕ) = aϕ + bϕ 3 (1) and
div.formula: W (ϕ) = d q (ϕ) dϕ = a + 3 bϕ 2(2)
div.p: where a > 0, b > 0, q is charge, ϕ is flux and W ( ϕ ) is memductance of flux-controlled memristor in circuit.

Unfortunately, it is impractical to use memristor device in circuit due to the immature production technology of memristor and the resulting high manufacturing cost. In order to solve this problem, some existing circuit components and integrated chips are invoked to construct a memristor emulator circuit behaving the unique characteristics of memristors.
According to the volt-ampere characteristics of the memristor, it can be easily concluded from (1) to (2) that
div.formula: i w = v w W (ϕ) = v w (a + 3 bϕ 2 ) ˙ ϕ = dϕ dt = v w (3
div.p: where i w and v w are current flowing through memristor and voltage across the memristor.

The schematic of the memristor emulator circuit is shown in Fig. 1 . The emulator circuit of memristor consists of 14 resistors, one capacitor, four amplifiers (AD712JN) and two multipliers (AD633JN) and they are all commercially available. In Fig. 1
div.formula: , R 1 , R 2 , R 3 , R 4 , R 5 , R 6 , R 7 are resistances, C is capacitor, V p , V e
div.p: are positive and negative voltage respectively and U 1 , U 2 , U 3 , U 4 are amplifiers. In addition, the whole memristor emulator circuit is packaged in a chip, which is powered by 15 V DC power supplies.

The first part in this circuit is a voltage follower U 1 and an integrator U 2 , which are both implemented by operational amplifiers. For integrators, the following equation can be obtained: Then there are two multipliers AD633JN. The output of the first multiplier is ϕ 2 and the output of the second multiplier is ϕ 2 v w . We can derive the equation from operational amplifier U 3 as follow:
div.formula: ϕ 2 v w R 3 + v w R 2 = -V 0 R 4 (5
div.p: where V 0 is the output voltage. It follows from ( 5) that
div.formula: V 0 = -v w R 4 R 3 ϕ 2 + R 4 R 2 . (6
div.p: The last operational amplifier U 4 is phase inverter and its role is to convert the input potential -V 0 into an inverted output potential V 0 .
The emulator circuit of memristor is invoked in the memristor chaotic circuit shown in Fig. 2 .

div.head: Remark 1.
div.p: It is worthy to point out that the proposed MCSs can be implemented via the circuit presented in Fig. 2 . In [40] , the memristor emulator circuit realized the cubic monotonous rise nonlinear characteristics by using a negative resistance which requires an active emulator circuit to be equivalent. Differently, in this paper, a phase inverter scheme is adopted to solve the previous design defect. Accordingly, the whole memristor emulator circuit can be implemented through available circuit components and integrated chips. In addition, the voltage follower is used to improve the stability and reliability of the presented emulator circuit.

div.head: Model description and problem formulation
div.p: According to Kirchhoff's current law, the memristor chaotic circuit shown in Fig. 2 yields the following MCS model:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ d v 1 dt = 1 RC 1 [ v 2 -v 1 + GR v 1 -RW (ϕ) v 1 ] d v 2 dt = 1 RC 2 [ v 1 -v 2 + Ri L ] d i L dt = - 1 L v 2 - r L i L dϕ dt = v 1(7)
div.p: where C 1 and C 2 are two capacitors, v 1 and v 2 are the voltages across two capacitors C 1 and C 2 respectively, -G is a negative conductance which denotes an active flux-controlled memristor with memristor model, R and r are two independent resistors, L is an inductor and i L is the current flowing through L .

Remark 2. Due to the unique nonlinear characteristics of the memristor, the MCSs show some chaotic characteristic curve which is different from the previous classical chaotic system Lorentz system and Chen system. These characteristics can bring better pseudo-random characteristics to chaotic signals generated by MCSs, which further improve the security of image encryption algorithms.

Remark 3. The MCS adopted in this paper is fourth-order. Compared with the fifth-order hyperchaotic system, the complexity of chaotic signal generated by the fourth-order MCS is sufficient. On the contrary, the fifth-order chaotic circuit will bring some difficulties to theoretical research and physical implementation, which is not necessary at present. In the future, the fourth-order MCS may no longer meet the application requirements with the development of technology, so we can further study the fifth-order hyperchaotic system in the future work.

div.head: Numerical simulations
div.p: In this section, the numerical simulations are given to show the effectiveness of the finite-time synchronization result.

Choose the parameters of system (8) as α 1 = 10 , α 2 = 2 , α 3 = -14 , α 4 = 0 . 1 and initial states as (x 1 , x 2 , x 3 , x 4 ) = (0 , 0 , 0 . 01 , 0) . Then the four-order Runge-Kutta method is adopted with time step size 0.001. Figs. 3 and4 show the 3D phase portraits and their 2D projections of the drive system (8) respectively. It can be seen from the Figs. 3 and4 that the drive system ( 8) is a chaotic system and it has two chaotic attractors.
Choose the initial states of system ( 9) as (y 1 , y 2 , y 3 , y 4 ) = (5 , -0 . 4 , 3 , -2) and the parameters of controller as
2 , then the conditions of Theorem 1 hold. From Lemma 1 , the synchronization time is

Fig. 5 shows the time behaviors of the error states. From Fig. 5 , the error states convergent to 0 in a finite time, which means that the drive system (8) and the response system (9) can achieve finite-time synchronization.

div.head: Image encryption algorithm and statistical performance analysis
div.p: Image encryption is one of the most important and common applications of synchronization of chaotic systems. First, we briefly introduce the DNA algorithm. It is well known that deoxyribonucleotide in DNA sequence can be divided into four types, including adenine (A), guanine (G), cytosine (C) and thymine (T). Similarly, there is also a complementary relationship between 0 and 1 in binary coding. According to the base pairing principle, there are eight kinds of DNA encoding for binary data, which is shown in Table 1 . By encoding binary data into a DNA sequence, we can choose anyone from the above eight encoding methods. Combining the above simple DNA sequence algorithm, an image encryption algorithm is proposed, whose encryption and decryption process are shown in Fig. 6 .

div.head: Remark 4.
div.p: The simple DNA sequence algorithm is used to improve the image encryption algorithm in this paper. This can expand key space, which can further improve the security of the algorithm.

div.head: Encryption process
div.p: The complete encryption steps are as follows:

1) Read an original image which is required to be encrypted and generate the corresponding plaintext matrix. The process of converting the original image into a plaintext matrix is to convert each pixel of the original image into a corresponding gray value first, and then arrange the gray values into plaintext matrix according to the position of the corresponding pixel.
2) The plaintext matrix is reorganized into the sequence h j according to certain rules and then sequence h j is converted to the DNA sequence h j .

3) Sampling process. The ode45 method is used to solve state equations of the MCS, sampling interval is T , the number of pixels in the image is a × b and the time interval is [ t 0 , t n ]. The following inequality must be satisfied during this process:
div.formula: t n -t 0 T ≥ a × b U (24
div.p: where U is the number of state variables in MCS. 4) Code discrete chaotic sequences. The encoding is as follows:

where i = 1 , 2 , . . . , n, a, b, c and d are random number between 0 and 256 (it is assumed that the image and key and other related discrete digits are all 8 bits long). Then we can get that p j = ω( j) mod 256 (26) 5) The binary sequence p j is converted to DNA sequence p j that are composed of "A, T, C, G" through DNA coding rules.

The DNA sequence p j is used as a final encryption key to encrypt data. 6) Encryption function. The encryption function executes an XOR operation between the sequence h j and the encryption key sequence p j , that is r j (t) = E(h j , p j ) = h j p j (27) where E ( x , y ) is bitwise XOR operation and r j is ciphertext sequence. 7) Finally, the DNA ciphertext sequence r j is converted into the binary ciphertext sequence r j and then the sequence r j is reassembled into a ciphertext matrix according to the previous rule 2). is obvious that the ciphertext matrix does not have any information of the original image all.

div.head: Decryption process
div.p: complete decryption steps are as follows:

Read the ciphertext image which is required to be decrypted and generate the corresponding ciphertext matrix. The process of converting the ciphertext into a ciphertext matrix is to convert each pixel of the ciphertext image into a corresponding gray value first, and then arrange the gray into ciphertext matrix according to the position of the corresponding pixel.
2) The ciphertext matrix is reorganized into the sequence j according to rules and then sequence r is to the sequence r j .
3) Sampling The specific process is as the same as the previous process in the encryption process. 4) Code discrete chaotic sequences. The encoding carried out follows:

where i = 1 , 2 , . . . , n, a, b, c and d are random number between 0 and 256. Then q j = ω ( j) mod (29) 5) The binary sequence q j is converted to DNA sequence q j through DNA encryption rules. The sequence q j is as a final decryption key to decrypt data. 6) Decryption function. The function executes an XOR operation between the sequence r j and the encryption key sequence q j , that is h j (t) E(r j , q j ) = r j q j (30) where E ( x , y ) is bitwise XOR operation and h j is plaintext sequence. 7) Note that r j (t) = h j (t) p j (t) = p j (t) q j (t) r j (t) (31) It is not difficult to see from the above formula that r j (t) = h j (t) when p j (t) = q j (t) . If we use the same DNA coding in Step 2 of encryption process and decryption process, r j (t) = h j (t) . In other words, as long as the drive system and the response system are synchronized, an encrypted transmission of image information can be achieved between the generator and the receiver.

The original image that is required to be encrypted is shown in Fig. 7 (a). Then, the encrypted image is obtained through encrypting the original image with an encryption algorithm, which is shown in Fig. 7 (b). The encrypted image look disorganized and it is difficult to interpret useful information from the encrypted image. Next, the decryption algorithm is implemented on the scrambled encrypted image and the decrypted image is Fig. 7 (c). It can be easily obtained that the decrypted image is almost indistinguishable from the original image before encryption. Remark 5. In [38] , an encryption scheme was proposed based on complex chaotic networks and the key sequence constitutes a package with ciphertext, which results in that the transmitted data can possibly be intercepted and cracked. Different from the encryption scheme in [38] , the scheme in this paper depends on the synchronization of MCSs, which avoids the case that the sender transmits the key sequence to the receiver over the channel and improves the safety in the transmission process of image encryption.

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: As one of the most important statistical methods, image histogram can demonstrate the effects and performance of image encryption techniques. Fig. 8 shows the histograms of the original RGB image separately whose distribution is extremely uneven and the histograms of the encrypted RGB image is shown in Fig. 9 with uniform distribution. In each figure, coordinate x indicates the gray level of pixels of the image and coordinate y indicates correspondingly the number of the pixels with certain gray level. Then statistical characteristics of the image are shown in the form of Histograms and a good encryption algorithm requires the gray value level evenly distributed. Hence, it is very difficult for attackers to obtain useful information from encrypted image by histogram analysis. Remark 6. In the earlier study of chaotic image encryption, the researchers used the conventional chaotic system and the most representative of which is the Logistic chaotic map. The Logistic chaotic map belongs to discrete chaotic system, then the effect of image encryption with this chaotic sequence is shown in Fig. 10 and the histograms of the encrypted image is shown in Fig. 11 . It is not hard to see from the pictures that the effect of encrypting images using conventional discrete chaotic systems is defective.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Finite-time synchronization is a hot topic in practical engineering. This paper has investigated the finite-time synchronization of MCSs via appropriate controller. An image encryption algorithm has been proposed based on the synchronization of MCSs. Compared to most previous image encryption algorithms, this one does not require that the sender transmits the key to the receiver over the channel, which may put the risk of the key being intercepted and cracked. In addition, the statistical analysis has been provided to demonstrate the application of image encryption algorithm.

Parameters uncertainties, external disturbances and delays are almost ubiquitous and difficult to avoid in the real world [41][42][43] . Thus, based on the requirements of the practical application, it is necessary to design a more general model containing the three factors. In the future, the finite-time robust synchronization of MCSs with parameters uncertainties, external disturbances and delays will be considered. Also, our work will focus on the design of more complex memristor chaotic circuits to implement the MCSs.
